awd_titl_txt: Structural Results in Floer Theory and Mirror Symmetry
awd_abstract_narration:
Symplectic geometry is an area broadly concerned with the global shape of physical systems, such as those tracking the possible positions and momenta of particles in a constrained configuration. Insights from mathematical physics have led to powerful tools, collectively called Floer theory, for extracting properties of such systems (for instance the number of periodic orbits associated to a system with given kinetic and potential energy); unfortunately the appearance of difficult differential equations makes these tools  challenging to apply.  This project seeks to simplify the study of Floer theory of a large class of spaces by developing systematic rules for computation (via e.g., cut and paste) and by establishing new relationships between different types of Floer theory.  Using these, the project aims to solve open problems about the structure of Floer theory and find new applications to mirror symmetry (a remarkable geometric duality first arising in string theory) and the study of singularities (abrupt changes) in symplectic geometry. The PI will also train and encourage mathematics students through workshops, new course and seminar content, and judging of K-12 science fairs.

This project aims to develop new structural results in Floer theory and mirror symmetry using input from (and with applications to) the study of singularities of various forms in symplectic geometry.  In one direction, the project aims to show that wrapped Fukaya categories satisfy expected van-Kampen style locality properties, and deduce as a consequence axiomatic and sheaf-theoretic characterizions of Fukaya categories of Stein manifolds (using in part the singular structure of their Lagrangian skeleta).  In a related direction, the project aims to geometrically calculate the Hochschild invariants of Fukaya categories associated to certain Landau-Ginzburg models (i.e., holomorphic functions), and deduce new applications to the study of singularities of such functions.  The third and final direction is to understand the effect of hidden singularities (in the sense of having a singular mirror) on Fukaya categories, with computational and structural consequences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Symplectic geometry is an area broadly concerned with the global shape of symplectic manifolds, mechanical systems tracking the allowable positions and momenta of particles in possibly constrained or symmetric configurations. Insights from mathematical physics have produced powerful geometric tools, collectively called "Floer theory", for measuring complexity of such systems (for instance the minimal number of physical trajectories satisfying certain properties).  These tools come in two distinct flavors, "open-string" (physically corresponding to studying trajectories with different endpoints) and "closed-string" (concerning periodic trajectories). The central tool of study in this project was an intricate structure known as the "Fukaya category" which collates many of the measurements from open-string Floer theory.

This project sought to develop new computational techniques and structure theorems for Floer theory - and specifically Fukaya categories - on a natural geometric class of symplectic manifolds known as "Weinstein manifolds (and sectors)".  This class encompasses both the "cotangent bundles" (or "phase spaces") of classical mechanics and the "smooth complex affine varieties" of algebraic geometry, and also arises by applying a suitable "large volume" limiting or expansion procedure to compact (finite-volume) symplectic manifolds such as the broad class of "complex projective varieties" from algebraic geometry. Many of the analytic aspects underlying Floer theory are simpler for Weinstein manifolds than their compact counterparts. However, there are also new complications arising from the unbounded non-compact nature of the geometry, which can be made manifest by a procedure known as "wrapping" that incorporates increasingly long and high momentum trajectories into Floer theoretic calculations.

The first outcome of the project was the realization of a longstanding expectation that Floer theory in large volume limits should be more topological in nature, hence amenable to "local-to-global" computations despite the complexities of wrapping. The project in particular established a new geometric toolkit for computing wrapped Fukaya categories, culminating in a cut-and-paste formula for reassembling the (wrapped) Fukaya categories of a Weinstein manifold/sector from simpler Fukaya categories associated to any suitable decomposition into smaller pieces. Using this toolkit the project also produced a completely algebraic - often algorithmically computable - formula for a large subclass of such Fukaya categories expressed in terms of "categories of microlocal sheaves." Applications have included a number of new computations, leading to proofs of previously unknown cases of Kontsevich's famous homological mirror symmetry conjecture, a proposed dictionary linking Fukaya categories to categories constructed in algebraic geometry.

The second outcome of the project was a study, from several perspectives, of the structural characteristics of Floer theory that are unique to the setting of Weinstein manifolds. In one direction, the project found new restrictions coming from closed string Floer theory on the classical problem of whether a given Weinstein manifold can be "Liouville embedded" into another one, and in particular be fit inside the other after possible rescaling.  In another direction, the project established an "infinite-or-zero" size principle for wrapped Floer theory on Weinstein manifolds, explaining an empirical phenomenon had been observed in all calculations which stands in stark contrast to the behavior of Floer theory in compact settings. Finally, the project studied algebraic measures coming from mirror symmetry which quantify "how infinite" a given wrapped Fukaya category is, establishing a new connection between such measures and new version of the Fukaya category built from open-string "Rabinowitz Floer theory" (a variation of Floer theory based upon a different action functional introduced in pioneering work of Rabinowitz on Hamiltonian systems in 1978).

The project also explored potential future directions in these and related areas. The topics developed in this project have so far provided training and subject material for 9 PhD students and 5 postdocs (including current and previous).
